hobby.message: Antique typewriter giving you trouble again?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: I manage. Quiet hobbies help. I fold paper, keeps my hands busy.
Lately not much time for it. Distractions everywhere.
Hard to focus with all the noise from those logs.
I’m alright. Still folding paper models when I can.
Origami, actually—it keeps me steady when things outside feel shaky.
This week was tough. Petitions at my building make it hard to concentrate.
My last model’s unfinished. Seems everyone’s on edge.
I try to keep steady. I fold origami—complex patterns, a mental anchor for me.
Kept at it even after news broke about the intervention logs.
Had a model started, but people kept coming by, asking questions.
Now I hesitate to touch my paper. The mood is...contagious.
It’s strange, how even harmless habits get caught in these events.
Honestly, it depends on the day. My origami is my reset button.
Folding tessellations, intricate grids—I lose track of time, or used to.
When they published Halden’s logs, the energy in my building changed.
I caught myself folding just to distract from anxiety. Even ruined a piece.
People think it’s just a quirky hobby, but it’s—well, it’s how I process change.
These days, every crease feels loaded with something I can’t quite name.
Not really steady, no. My origami got me through audits, bad weeks—most things.
I started with cranes years ago, but I do tessellations now, stuff you plan out for hours.
Tuesday night, after the logs leaked, I tried to refold an old hydrangea design.
Neighbors kept knocking, passing around petitions, asking about the system. Couldn’t focus.
I realized I was folding to forget my job, not because I enjoyed it.
Funny how a paper model can feel like incriminating evidence now.
My work used to be invisible, like a crease inside the paper.
Now, it’s all exposed, and even my hobby feels suspect.
hobby_answer: Folded one, yes. Nothing fancy.
Not easy lately. Neighborhood's loud since the logs leak.
Paper's hard to get, people watching.
I keep it simple, just for myself.
Best not to display much now.
Yeah, a crane yesterday. Used old receipts.
Feels risky—since those intervention logs hit, neighbors knock more than before.
I stick to folding alone now.
Hard to relax with people talking outside.
Paper scraps harder to save these days.
I try not to draw attention with it.
Made a new waterbomb base last night—old habit.
Origami used to be quiet. Now, after the logs... it's tense.
Every time someone knocks, I flinch. Asking about BCI, or the hobby.
Paper's just paper, but people search for signs now.
I still fold at home, but I keep it hidden.
The city's so restless.
I haven't started a big piece in weeks.
Folded a modular star—scrap invoices, nothing pretty.
I always liked precise patterns. Kept my mind occupied after work.
Now, every time I fold, I think of who's watching.
After Halden's logs dropped, hallway's full of loud voices and suspicion.
Someone knocked last night, hinted my hobby means something else.
Makes me hesitate—like, even a harmless thing isn't safe.
I'm careful about which instruction books I leave out.
Honestly, I miss when it was just paper and quiet.
Yeah. Last night I tried a Kawasaki rose, out of a ration slip.
Origami was always my escape, structure without consequence.
Now, since the intervention logs, people think patterns mean secret codes.
I used to fold in the canteen, but now even at home I worry.
Yesterday, a neighbor called my hobby suspicious—with my BCI, that's dangerous.
Feels like every crease is watched, every choice has meaning.
Other days, I skip it to avoid rumors. That's new for me.
I remember showing Halden a simple cube once. He joked it was more honest than the system.
Now, even folding paper feels like a risk. Can't believe that's true.
